Occasionally,
N. meningitidis
may invade the bloodstream and cause life-threatening disease such as meningitis and/or septicaemia [ 2]. Meningococcal disease occurs endemically throughout the world, but in a region designated as the meningitis belt in sub-Saharan Africa, outbreaks and epidemics occur every year in the dry season. During these epidemics, carriage prevalence of the outbreak strain can increase by a factor of 10 or more [ 3].
